Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story:
I glanced at the family calendar on the fridge, the words “Family Gathering – 6 PM” circled in my granddaughter’s careful handwriting. She’d been talking about it for weeks, excited to show me her new drawings and play our favorite board game. My daughter had called earlier, reminding me not to be late this time. I promised her I wouldn’t miss it.

But just as I was about to leave the shop, my phone buzzed. The plant manager’s voice was tense: “The main unit’s down again. Sensor errors. We need you, now.” I could hear the urgency—every minute the line was stopped meant lost revenue, angry clients, and pressure from above. I was the only one who really understood that old machine’s quirks.

I stood in the doorway, keys in hand, torn between the warmth of my family waiting at home and the cold, humming machines that needed my expertise. My heart ached at the thought of disappointing my granddaughter, but I also felt the weight of responsibility to my team. The clock ticked, and I wrestled with the impossible choice, feeling pulled in two directions by the people who needed me most.
